content.description: A slabby pillar, with several sidepulls around the left arete.
content.location: From parking, walk towards the largest tree, which is circled by a "turn around" dirt path.  The boulder is located to the south west of the tree and is visible from there.

content.description: Start low on the obvious crack, move your feet up and stand up on it.  Lean left and get a left foot in a divot (which looks like was made from a bullet) and move upwards to an easy finish.
content.location: From the parking this is the most obvious and large rock facing west, perched up on a small hill.  It has a dark circular divot in it.

content.description: Start far right, on a circular flake system. Work up and left, to top out above a bowl feature.
content.location: From the parking, look for the largest and most prominent free standing boulder.  Walk around the north west side of it, where the rock is noticeably darker.  To the left of Bloody Bullet.

content.description: Too crowded at Groom Creek? Love avoiding broken glass and cacti? Is petting sharp granite a picture of your ideal way to spend an afternoon? If you answered yes to any of these, then come on down to the Bloody Basin Boulders. Or don't. Seriously, I don't recommend it. Watch out for hunters, atv riders, wild animals, spine laden desert flora, and UV rays. The only plus side to this tiny rock pile is that it is up at almost 4k feet of elevation, and a bit cooler than the Phoenix temps.TLDR: Don't make the mistake I did and turn off the highway thinking you can find some gem of a boulder. Like Ackbar said, "It's a trap!"
